NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I came here on purpose to see you.

NewWords.WordPhrase: ahead in time 预先,事先
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You must pay for the book in advance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. have as parts or members 包含,包括;由…组成
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The committee comprises men of widely different views.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. make a movement that tells (sb.) what to do 以动作示意
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She motioned to the waiter.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. become suited (to new conditions, etc.) 适应
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You can't see well through a telescope unless it is adjusted correctly to your sight.

NewWords.WordPhrase: produce by thought; devise 想出;设计出
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There's no knowing what he'll think up next.

NewWords.WordPhrase: meanwhile 在此期间;与此同时
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Please find a taxi, and in the meantime I'll pack some food.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. attraction; interest 感染力;吸引力
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. That sort of music hasn't much appeal for me.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. fight or serious disagreement 冲突
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. There is a clash of views between us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. stand for or be a sign or symbol of 代表;象征
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We chose a committee to represent us.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. honest and respectable 正派的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Poor people cannot always live in decent conditions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. great wickedness 邪恶    a. wicked, very bad 邪恶的,极坏的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The love of money is the root of all evils.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. acting or done willingly 自愿的;自动的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She is a voluntary worker at the hospital.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. suppose (sth.) to be a fact 假定,假设
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. You assume that he is innocent before hearing the evidence against him.
